needs.description: Over 1,000 residential buildings damaged in January 2026 shelling, leaving ~150,000 people without adequate housing. Winter temperatures averaging -10°C increase hypothermia and respiratory illness risks.
Only 3 of 8 hospitals fully operational; 12,000 trauma cases reported since January 2026. Medical supply shortages include 60% deficit in surgical kits and anesthetics.
Shelling damaged 40% of water infrastructure; 600,000 people face intermittent water supply. Sewage system failures raise cholera outbreak risk.
IPC Phase 3 (Crisis) conditions affect 320,000 residents; food prices up 45% since December 2025 due to supply chain disruption.
60,000 new IDPs registered in Kharkiv Oblast since January 2026; collective centers operating at 150% capacity.

needs.description: Dnieper River water intake damaged; 350,000 people rely on bottled water distribution. Sewage overflow reported in 12 districts.
Only 2 hospitals fully functional; 8,500 patients treated for waterborne diseases since January 2026, including 1,200 confirmed hepatitis A cases.
Agricultural land heavily mined; 40% of arable land inaccessible. 180,000 residents in IPC Phase 2 (Stressed) or worse.
Reports of 450 civilian casualties from mines/UXO since January 2026; child protection cases up 35%.

needs.description: Constant shelling destroyed 3,200 homes in Bakhmut and Avdiivka since December 2025; 85,000 people live in damaged buildings.
Only 1 operational hospital serving 200,000 people; 5,600 trauma cases since January 2026. Medicine stockouts include insulin (80% deficit).
IPC Phase 4 (Emergency) conditions in Bakhmut area affect 45,000 people; food aid deliveries blocked by active hostilities.
25,000 people newly displaced within Donetsk Oblast since January 2026; 60% are elderly with limited mobility.
